title: Hilbert's 11th Problem
content:
**Hilbert's 11th Problem (1900)**:

> Classify quadratic forms with algebraic number coefficients.

Specifically: When does Q(x₁,...,xₙ) = Σaᵢⱼxᵢxⱼ have a nontrivial zero?

**Answer: The Hasse-Minkowski Theorem**

A quadratic form over ℚ has a nontrivial zero iff it has zeros:
- Over ℝ (indefinite)
- Over ℚₚ for all primes p

This is the **local-global principle** for quadratic forms.

title: Key Definitions
content:
**Isotropic Form**: Q represents zero nontrivially.
$$\exists x \neq 0 : Q(x) = 0$$

**Anisotropic Form**: Q does NOT represent zero nontrivially.

**Equivalent Forms**: Q₁ ~ Q₂ if there's an isometry between them (a linear bijection preserving values).

These definitions apply over any field: ℚ, ℝ, ℚₚ, etc.

title: Sylvester's Law of Inertia
content:
**Sylvester's Law (1852)**:

Every real quadratic form is equivalent to a diagonal form:
$$x_1^2 + \cdots + x_p^2 - x_{p+1}^2 - \cdots - x_{p+q}^2$$

The **signature (p,q)** is unique and completely classifies real quadratic forms!

- p = number of positive eigenvalues
- q = number of negative eigenvalues
- Indefinite means p > 0 and q > 0

title: Hasse-Minkowski Theorem
content:
**THE MAIN THEOREM**:

A quadratic form Q over ℚ represents zero nontrivially iff:
1. Q is indefinite over ℝ (signature has both + and −)
2. Q represents zero over ℚₚ for ALL primes p

**Timeline**:
- 1890: Minkowski proves for ternary forms
- 1923: Hasse extends to all dimensions

**The local-global principle**: Check solvability locally everywhere, conclude globally!

title: Four Squares Theorem
content:
**Lagrange's Theorem (1770)**:

Every positive integer is a sum of four squares:
$$n = a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + d^2$$

In quadratic form language: The form x₁² + x₂² + x₃² + x₄² represents ALL positive integers.

This connects to Hilbert 11 through representation theory of quaternary forms.

title: Classification Theory
content:
**Complete Classification of Rational Quadratic Forms**:

Two forms over ℚ are equivalent iff they have the same:
1. **Dimension** n
2. **Discriminant** (in ℚ*/ℚ*²)
3. **Hasse-Witt invariants** εₚ = ±1 at each prime p and at ∞

The Hasse-Minkowski theorem ensures these **local invariants** completely determine the global equivalence class!

title: Witt Ring Structure
content:
**The Witt Ring W(F)**:

The Grothendieck ring of quadratic forms modulo hyperbolic forms.

**Hyperbolic Plane**: H = ⟨1, −1⟩ (represents both +1 and −1)

**Witt Cancellation**: If Q₁ ⊥ Q ≅ Q₂ ⊥ Q, then Q₁ ≅ Q₂

This allows algebraic manipulation of quadratic forms as ring elements!

title: Failure for Higher Degree
content:
**The Selmer Curve (1951)**:

$$3x^3 + 4y^3 + 5z^3 = 0$$

has points over ℝ and ALL ℚₚ, but **NO rational points**!

This shows the **Hasse principle FAILS for cubics**.

**Why quadratics are special**: The Brauer-Manin obstruction is trivial for quadratic forms, so local-global works. For cubics and higher, additional obstructions exist.

title: Meyer's Theorem
content:
**Meyer's Theorem**:

Any quadratic form in **≥ 5 variables** over ℚₚ is always isotropic!

Consequence: For forms in ≥ 5 variables, checking local solvability reduces to:
- Check ℝ (indefiniteness)
- Check finitely many "bad" primes

Dimension 5 is the threshold for automatic local solvability.

title: Hilbert Symbol & Reciprocity
content:
**Hilbert Symbol (a,b)ₚ**:

= +1 if ax² + by² = z² has a nontrivial ℚₚ solution
= −1 otherwise

**Hilbert Reciprocity**:
$$\prod_p (a,b)_p = 1$$

for all a, b ∈ ℚ*. This generalizes quadratic reciprocity and connects quadratic forms to class field theory!

title: Problem Status
content:
**Hilbert 11: Partially Solved**

**Solved**:
- Hasse-Minkowski for ℚ (complete)
- Classification by local invariants
- Witt ring theory

**Open**:
- Explicit algorithms over general number fields
- Connections to Langlands program
- Higher reciprocity phenomena

**Impact**: Local-global philosophy is now central to algebraic number theory and arithmetic geometry.
